name: The Tortoise and the Hare
text: Once upon a time, a speedy hare mocked a slow-moving tortoise for being so slow.
The tortoise, tired of the hare's teasing, challenged him to a race.
The hare, overconfident, took a nap midway through, believing he had plenty of time.
But the tortoise kept going steadily, step by step.
When the hare woke up, he rushed to the finish line, only to find the tortoise had already won.
The lesson: Slow and steady wins the race.

name: The Boy Who Cried Wolf
text: There was once a shepherd boy who liked to play tricks.
He would shout, 'Wolf! Wolf!' and villagers would come running to help him.
When they found no wolf, he would laugh at them.
One day, a real wolf came, and the boy cried for help.
But the villagers thought it was another trick and didn't come, and the wolf ate the sheep.
The lesson: Honesty is the best policy; if you lie too often, no one will believe you when you tell the truth.

name: The Lion and the Mouse
text: A lion once caught a little mouse and was about to eat it.
The mouse begged for mercy, promising to help the lion one day.
The lion laughed but let the mouse go.
Later, the lion was caught in a hunter's net.
The little mouse gnawed through the ropes and set the lion free, proving that kindness is never wasted.
The lesson: No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted.

name: The Ant and the Grasshopper
text: All summer long, the ant worked hard storing food for winter.
Meanwhile, the grasshopper played and sang, laughing at the busy ant.
When winter came, the grasshopper had no food and was starving.
He went to the ant to beg for food.
The ant replied, 'You should have prepared for winter instead of just playing all summer.'
The lesson: It's wise to prepare for the future and not just live for the moment.
